Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Situation2: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Story: I glanced at my phone at a red light, heart sinking as I read my friend’s message: “Wow, didn’t know you felt that way.” The words stung. I hadn’t meant my text to sound harsh, but clearly, something had gone wrong. I knew I should call right away, clear things up before the misunderstanding grew. That’s what friends do—talk things out, make sure no one’s left hurting. But in the rearview mirror, my passenger was humming along to the radio, relaxed, expecting a smooth, safe ride to their meeting. I was on the clock, responsible for their safety, and I couldn’t just pull over or get distracted. My phone buzzed again, my friend’s name lighting up the screen. My hands tightened on the wheel. I felt torn—my friend needed me, but so did my passenger. The urge to fix things with my friend battled with my duty to drive responsibly. I could feel the pressure building, caught between being the friend who’s always there and the driver who never lets anyone down.
